section.title: Countable and uncountable nouns
section.sectiontitle: Countable nouns are words like jacket or hotel. They can use a singular or plural form of the verb.
section.sectiontitle2: You can use a / an, few, a few, some, any, many, a lot of, lots of, before countable nouns.
section.text3a: There were a lot of people who arrived late.

section.title: Countable and uncountable nouns
section.sectiontitle: Uncountable nouns use a singular form of the verb. Common uncountable nouns are: advice, behaviour, health, information, knowledge, luggage, news, research, traffic, travel, water, weather and work.
section.sectiontitle2: You can use little, a little, some, any, much, a lot of, lots of, before uncountable nouns.
section.text4a: There was a lot of traffic this morning.

section.title: Countable and uncountable nouns
section.sectiontitle: Some nouns can be countable or uncountable. Common examples are: chicken, chocolate, coffee, egg, glass, hair, iron, paper, room, space, time, wine.
section.text2a: Oh no! There's a hair in my soup!

section.title: Countable and uncountable nouns
section.sectiontitle: Few and little (without 'a') are used to talk about negative ideas.
section.text1a: She's got few friends and is quite lonely.
section.text2a: He's got little money and can't afford a new car.
section.sectiontitle2: A few and a little are used to talk about more positive ideas.
section.text3a: I've got a few biscuits left. Would you like one?
section.text4a: Could I have tea with a little milk, please?
